body:
Hm, seems like this is generation `Facings: 0` values, which is not correct (e.g. import the sequences of the rocketeer and look at its idle definitions) and on other sequences it used `Facings: 6` where it should be 8 (probably not your fault, as the value is really 6, but the assets browser shows me 8 facings...).

GJ otherwise.

It indeed has some quirks. For example the `stand` sequence always needs to be corrected to:

``` diff
    stand:
-       Start: 0
-       Length: 1
-       Facings: 1
    stand:
+       Start: 0
+       Length: 6
+       Facings: 8
```

Those definitions seem to have different meanings for each type although the enumeration looks identical.

That 0 1 1 stand looks legit though (with my suggested fix), TS/RA2 couldn't use more frames for idling at all, jumpjet infantry are a giant hack itself, your 0 6 8 fix sounds wrong to me instead tbh. `Length` shouldn't be increased.
Thanks, added your suggested fixes and some more infantry sequences such as die, panic and cheer.
:+1: Looks good to me now.
Any progress here?
Technically this doesn't need a progress (excluding the header). I think this is done but haven't found time to check the output to give my thumb.
The header is what i'm referring to.
Updated with the 2016 copyright header.
You missed `LegacySequenceImporter`.
Fixed.

You have access to the footprint information, so really should generate the appropriate artwork offsets for buildings (or at least something that is approximately correct).  Ignoring them here and then doing them all by hand (https://github.com/OpenRA/ra2/issues/159) is a giant waste of effort and potential for this tool.
Really, I thought that information just wasn't available and all the TS offsets were corrected manually?
It's not available to the OpenRA sprite sequence parsers because it depends on the building footprints, which are stored in the rules.  You have access to the building foundation here.

For reference:

In TS/RA2 the center of the SHP was the building's top-right (in isometric perspective, the top corner) cells top pixel. OpenRA assumes the center of the SHP is the building's middle.

Besides the footprints, it is based on the actual cell's size, and the offset math is also quite complex at non-square footprints (y offset will always be cellheight*y/2 but the x I'm not certain about, at square footprints, it's 0, but notsure at the rest, might be cellwidth*(x-y)/2 but I'm just guessing).

Including this here might be more complicated than the rest which are universal and shared between TS and RA2 which is why I felt that's being out-of-scope here.

Attaching a picture from SHP Builder with TS cellsize to point this out further - although it's known SHP Builder mispositions this grid some pixels away, probably due to rounding errors.

![shpbuildertsgrid](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1136302/13898900/b1ab53e4-ede0-11e5-9a1e-51ca284c36a3.png)

Adding support for automatic building offset generation would be nice.
Needs a rebase in any case.

Rebased and added the offset guessing, which is indeed an excellent idea and your suggestions work rather good in practice https://github.com/OpenRA/ra2/pull/224 as most houses have a square footprint.
The offsets are imported incorrectly for all the rectangular footprints that I checked in TS.  Please fix the calculation so that these are done correctly

I don't see any pattern to be honest:

Dimensions: 4,3

``` patch
gaweap:
    Defaults:
-       Offset: 0,-36
+       Offset: -12, -42
```

Dimensions: 3,2

``` patch
nahand:
    Defaults:
-       Offset: 0,-24
+       Offset: -6, -30
```

Dimensions: 2,3

``` patch
naapwr:
    Defaults:
-       Offset: -24,-36
+       Offset: 12, -30
```

Are we even sure that the current TS offsets are correct?
Your best test cases will be the TS gates, which are currently imported with an offset that is wrong by multiple cells.

Dimensions: 3,1

``` patch
gagate_a:
    Defaults:
-       Offset: 48,-12
+       Offset: -24, -24
```

Dimensions: 1,3

``` patch
gagate_b:
    Defaults:
-       Offset: -48,-36
+       Offset: 24, -24
```
Removed 718107bbc50003398141957655ed6bb1f4e45641, because while this is a good idea, it is a large enough feature for its own pull request and this one already in development for 4 months.

From above:

> You have access to the footprint information, so really should generate the appropriate artwork offsets 
> for buildings (or at least something that is approximately correct). Ignoring them here and then doing
> them all by hand (OpenRA/ra2#159) is a giant waste of effort and potential for this tool.

I don't think it is fair to ask us to merge an unfinished tool upstream just because you don't want to work through the equations to finish it.  That _forces_ the burden of effort onto someone else, compared with _asking_ for help and receiving it on their timescale.

This is not a large change, nor is it complex in terms of plumbing.  You have all the info you need to, you are only having problems with the two lines of code that generate the output numbers.
In fact I removed the commit to not submit unfinished code, but only proven one.

`FootprintUtils.CenterOffset` gives you the offset between the center of the top-left cell and the center of the actor.  You can reuse that equation, adding 512 to Y and then multiplying by the tile pixel size / 1024.

Updated with an improved version of the building offset converter thanks to your help. I just changed the sign and divided the X offset by 2. Updated https://github.com/OpenRA/ra2/pull/224 where the map "Powder Keg" is a good test case, because it features a lot of buildings that are aligned to the street tiles.
This now spits out `Stride: 0` for everything that doesn't need it, and all the non-zero values are negative.

After a quick inspection of the rules myself it looks like splitting[2] is the stride in cases where it is nonzero.  It should only be exported if it is different to splitting[1] and not equal to zero.
Updated the stride calculation with your recent findings.
